abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Social Development Fund
            (SDF) Project for Senegal were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory; the risk to development outcome was moderate;
            Bank performance was satisfactory; and the Borrower
            performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            the use of an effective project management structure for
            piloting innovative approaches. In this case, the
            semi-autonomous structure of the SDF agency balanced with
            its placement in the social development ministry and
            overseen by a multi-sectoral Board allowed for the
            establishment of a high caliber team and integration with
            broader poverty reduction and sectoral policies. This
            ability to adapt was critical in developing more cost
            effective capacity building strategies and in capturing
            opportunities in the poverty monitoring component, like
            funding Senegal's development gateway. Building on the
            strengths of civic engagement and civil society to overcome
            capacity constraints on the public sector side in reaching
            the poorest communities and in developing ownership and
            self-help spirit that drove positive outcomes at the
            community level. An emphasis on capacity building and
            communications as an integral part of community investments.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Development Fund Project will
            support capacity building for poor communities, to
            effectively manage their development resources, and,
            economic, and social services, based on the following
            project components. 1) Communities, in particular vulnerable
            groups, will have improved access to basic social services,
            and infrastructure, through sustainable processes. From the
            demand perspective, the component will support subprojects
            aiming at developing structures that improve access to basic
            social services by the community, such as a micro-project
            promoting the use of technology to preserve milk, enabling
            its transportation for market sale. On the supply side, the
            aim is to attract social services providers, such as funding
            a micro-project for the promotion of a youth-run
            Information/Education/Communication campaign. The objectives
            will be phased by setting institutional arrangements,
            monitoring and evaluation, and scaling up implementation
            through communal participatory poverty assessments. 2) The
            micro-finance component will extend financial services
            focusing on social intermediation, facilitating the creation
            of savings and credit associations. 3) The capacity building
            component will organize the most vulnerable groups, through
            an institutional development phase to set up their
            operational capacity, financial, and project management
            abilities. 4) A baseline data and information system will be
            developed to trace poverty alleviation programs for
            executing agencies, social fund Boards, Ministries, and
            donors, and, institutional systems will be created for
            integration of social funds, within community-based mechanisms.

repnme.cdata!:
Senegal - Social Development Fund Project :
            environmental assessment (executive summary only)

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment of
            the Social Development Fund Project, which uses social funds
            in priority development areas in the poorest regions of
            Senegal and focuses on vulnerable groups, particularly,
            women. Loss of biodiversity and pollution and nuisance will
            be alleviated by promoting ecologically adapted construction
            methods and material, training beneficiaries, and funding
            reforestation projects. These measures will arrest
            vegetative degradation on access roads used for transport.
            Building latrines in rural areas will minimize health risks
            associated with fecal contamination and water pollution.
            Appropriate waste collection and disposal procedures as well
            as recycling will be used to prevent solid, liquid, and
            biomedical waste from becoming a health hazard. Watering and
            nursing trees will diminish water availability. Greater
            reliance will be placed on using organic fertilizer to avoid
            adding to soil and water pollution. This report also focuses
            on reducing the risk of expansion of Sexually Transmitted
            Diseases (STDs) and Acquired Immune Deficiency Disease
            (AIDS) related to the migration of the labor force and to
            the potential risk of changes in sexual behavior; these can
            be reduced by improving income and inappropriately handling
            biomedical waste.
